Title: English auction
Description:
A user should be able to create a English auction. In an [English auction](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_auction):
 - The auction starts with a suggested opening bid
 - Bids must be higher than the current "standing" bid
 - Users can see other users bids
 - There are multiple rounds
 - The auction finishes when everybody passes in a round
 - The winner is decided by the highest bid
 - The winning value is the highest bid

Title: Vickrey auction
Description:
A user should be able to create a Vickrey auction. In a [Vickrey auction](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vickrey_auction):
 - The auction starts with a suggested opening bid
 - Bids must be higher than the opening bid
 - Users cannot see other users bids (assuming they cannot see previous lines in CLI)
 - There are multiple rounds
 - The auction finishes when everybody passes in a round
 - The winner is decided by the highest bid
 - The winning value is the second highest bid

Title: Dutch auction
Description:
A user should be able to create a Dutch auction. In a [Dutch auction](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_auction):
 - There are multiple rounds, 
 - In each round, a price is offered to players, initially using the starting price, and then counting down on each subsequent round
 - Players can either accept the offered price, or pass
 - The winner is the first player to accept an offer
 - The winning value is the accepted price

Title: Fixed Price Computer bidder
Description: A user should be able to create a auction with a fixed price computer bidder. A fixed price computer bidder will only make one bid at the specified value as soon as possible.

Title: Multiply Price Computer bidder
Description: A user should be able to create a auction with a Multiply Price computer bidder. A Multiply Price computer bidder will multiply the value of any previously seen bids by a specified factor until all previous bidders have passed in the current round. If the auction is blind, it should attempt to multiply the starting price.
